Provision.Text: The Chairperson of the Immigration and Refugee Board, pursuant to subsection 161(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Acta, and subject to the approval of the Governor in Council, in consultation with the Deputy Chairpersons and the Director General of the Immigration Division, makes the annexed Refugee Protection Division Rules.

SignatureTitle.Emphasis: Chairperson of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Provision.Text: His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, pursuant to subsection 161(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Acta, approves the annexed Refugee Protection Division Rules, made by the Chairperson of the Immigration and Refugee Board, in consultation with the Deputy Chairpersons and the Director General of the Immigration Division.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in these Rules.

Definition.Text: Act means the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: Formulaire de fondement de la demande d’asile

Definition.Text: Basis of Claim Form means the form in which a claimant gives the information referred to in Schedule 1.
contact information means, with respect to a person,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s name, postal address and telephone number, and their fax number and email address, if any; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of counsel for a claimant or protected person, if the counsel is a person referred to in any of paragraphs 91(2)(a) to (c) of the Act, in addition to the information referred to in paragraph (a), the name of the body of which the counsel is a member and the membership identification number issued to the counsel.

Definition.Text: Division means the Refugee Protection Division.
officer means a person designated as an officer by the Minister under subsection 6(1) of the Act.

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a claim for refugee protection, the claimant and, if the Minister intervenes in the claim, the Minister; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an application to vacate or to cease refugee protection, the protected person and the Minister.

Definition.Text: proceeding includes a conference, an application or a hearing.
registry office means a business office of the Division.
Regulations means the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations.

vulnerable person means a person who has been identified as vulnerable under the Guideline on Procedures with Respect to Vulnerable Persons Appearing Before the IRB issued under paragraph 159(1)(h) of the Act.
working day does not include Saturdays, Sundays or other days on which the Board offices are closed.

Section.Text: All communication with the Division must be directed to the registry office specified by the Division.

Heading.TitleText: Information and Documents to Be Provided

Section.MarginalNote: Fixing date, time and location of hearing

Subsection.Text: As soon as a claim for refugee protection is referred to the Division, or as soon as possible before it is deemed to be referred under subsection 100(3) of the Act, an officer must fix a date, time and location for the claimant to attend a hearing on the claim, within the time limits set out in the Regulations, from the dates, times and locations provided by the Division.
Subject to paragraph 3(b), the officer must select the date closest to the last day of the applicable time limit set out in the Regulations, unless the claimant agrees to an earlier date.
In fixing the date, time and location for the hearing, the officer must consider

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant’s preference of location; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: counsel’s availability, if the claimant has retained counsel at the time of referral and the officer has been informed that counsel will be available to attend a hearing on one of the dates provided by the Division.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Providing information to claimant in writing
Subsection.Text: The officer must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notify the claimant in writing by way of a notice to appear

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: of the date, time and location of the hearing of the claim; and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: of the date, time and location of any special hearing on the abandonment of the claim under subrules 65(2) and (3);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: unless the claimant has provided a completed Basis of Claim Form to the officer in accordance with subsection 99(3.1) of the Act, provide to the claimant the Basis of Claim Form; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: provide to the claimant information in writing

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: explaining how and when to provide a Basis of Claim Form and other documents to the Division and to the Minister,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: informing the claimant of the importance of obtaining relevant documentary evidence without delay,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: explaining how the hearing will proceed,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: informing the claimant of the obligation to notify the Division and the Minister of the claimant’s contact information and any changes to that information,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: informing the claimant that they may, at their own expense, be represented by legal or other counsel, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: informing the claimant that the claim may be declared abandoned without further notice if the claimant fails to provide the completed Basis of Claim Form or fails to appear at the hearing.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Providing information in writing and documents to Division
Subsection.Text: After providing to the claimant the information set out in subrule (4), the officer must without delay provide to the Division

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a written statement indicating how and when the information set out in subrule (4) was provided to the claimant;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the completed Basis of Claim Form for a claimant referred to in subsection 99(3.1) of the Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of each notice to appear provided to the claimant in accordance with paragraph (4)(a);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the information set out in Schedule 2;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of any identity and travel documents of the claimant that have been seized by the officer;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the notice of seizure of any seized documents referred to in paragraph (e); and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of any other relevant documents that are in the possession of the officer.

Subsection.Text: The officer must provide to the claimant a copy of any documents or information that the officer has provided to the Division under paragraphs (5)(d) to (g).
The claimant must provide their contact information in writing to the Division and to the Minister.

The claimant’s contact information must be received by the Division and the Minister no later than 10 days after the day on which the claimant receives the information provided by the officer under subrule 3(4).
If the claimant’s contact information changes, the claimant must without delay provide the changes in writing to the Division and to the Minister.

A claimant who is represented by counsel must without delay, on retaining counsel, provide the counsel’s contact information in writing to the Division and to the Minister and notify them of any limitations on the counsel’s retainer. If that information changes, the claimant must without delay provide the changes in writing to the Division and to the Minister.

Section.MarginalNote: Declaration — counsel not representing or advising for consideration
Section.Text: If a claimant retains counsel who is not a person referred to in any of paragraphs 91(2)(a) to (c) of the Act, both the claimant and their counsel must without delay provide the information and declarations set out in Schedule 3 to the Division in writing.

Subsection.Text: The claimant must complete a Basis of Claim Form and sign and date the declaration set out in the form stating that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the information given by the claimant is complete, true and correct; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant understands that the declaration is of the same force and effect as if made under oath.

Subsection.Text: If the claimant completes the Basis of Claim Form without an interpreter’s assistance, the claimant must sign and date the declaration set out in the form stating that they can read the language of the form and understand what information is requested.
If the claimant completes the Basis of Claim Form with an interpreter’s assistance, the interpreter must sign and date the declaration in the form stating that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they are proficient in the language and dialect, if any, used, and were able to communicate effectively with the claimant;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the completed Basis of Claim Form and all attached documents were interpreted to the claimant; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant indicated that the claimant understood what was interpreted.

Section.MarginalNote: Providing Basis of Claim Form — inland claim

Subsection.Text: A claimant referred to in subsection 99(3.1) of the Act must provide the original and a copy of the completed Basis of Claim Form to the officer referred to in rule 3.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Providing Basis of Claim Form — port of entry claim
Subsection.Text: A claimant other than a claimant referred to in subsection 99(3.1) of the Act must provide the original and a copy of the completed Basis of Claim Form to the Division.

The claimant must attach to the original and to the copy of the completed Basis of Claim Form a copy of their identity and travel documents, genuine or not, and a copy of any other relevant documents in their possession. The claimant does not have to attach a copy of a document that has been seized by an officer or provided to the Division by an officer.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Documents obtained after providing Basis of Claim Form
Subsection.Text: If the claimant obtains an identity or travel document after the Division has received the completed Basis of Claim Form, they must provide two copies of the document to the Division without delay.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Providing Basis of Claim Form — port of entry claim
Subsection.Text: The Basis of Claim Form provided under subrule (2) must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: received by the Division within the time limit set out in the Regulations, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provided in any of the following ways:

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: by fax if the document is no more than 20 pages long, unless the Division consents to receiving more than 20 pages, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: by email or other electronic means if the Division allows.

Subsection.Text: A claimant who provides the Basis of Claim Form by fax must provide the original to the Division at the beginning of the hearing.

A claimant who makes an application for an extension of time to provide the completed Basis of Claim Form must make the application in accordance with rule 50, but the claimant is not required to give evidence in an affidavit or statutory declaration.
The application must be received by the Division no later than three working days before the expiry of the time limit set out in the Regulations.

If a claimant makes the application for medical reasons, other than those related to their counsel, they must provide, together with the application, a legible, recently dated medical certificate signed by a qualified medical practitioner whose name and address are printed or stamped on the certificate. A claimant who has provided a copy of the certificate to the Division must provide the original document to the Division without delay.

The medical certificate must set out the particulars of the medical condition, without specifying the diagnosis, that prevent the claimant from providing the completed Basis of Claim Form in the time limit referred to in paragraph 7(5)(a).
If a claimant fails to provide a medical certificate in accordance with subrules (3) and (4), the claimant must include in their application

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: particulars of any efforts they made to obtain the required medical certificate, supported by corroborating evidence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: particulars of the medical reasons for the application, supported by corroborating evidence; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an explanation of how the medical condition prevents them from providing the completed Basis of Claim Form in the time limit referred to in paragraph 7(5)(a).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Providing Basis of Claim Form after extension granted
Subsection.Text: If an extension of time is granted, the claimant must provide the original and a copy of the completed Basis of Claim Form to the Division in accordance with subrules 7(2) and (3), no later than on the date indicated by the Division and by a means set out in paragraph 7(5)(b).

Section.MarginalNote: Changes or additions to Basis of Claim Form

Subsection.Text: To make changes or add any information to the Basis of Claim Form, the claimant must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide to the Division the original and a copy of each page of the form to which changes or additions have been made;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sign and date each new page and underline the changes or additions made; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: sign and date a declaration stating that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the information given by the claimant in the Basis of Claim Form, together with the changes and additions, is complete, true and correct, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the claimant understands that the declaration is of the same force and effect as if made under oath.

Subsection.Text: The documents referred to in subrule (1) must be provided to the Division without delay and must be received by it no later than 10 days before the date fixed for the hearing.
In a hearing of a claim for refugee protection, if the Minister is not a party, any witness, including the claimant, will be questioned first by the Division and then by the claimant’s counsel.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Order of questioning — Minister’s intervention on exclusion issue
Subsection.Text: In a hearing of a claim for refugee protection, if the Minister is a party and has intervened on an issue of exclusion under subrule 29(3), any witness, including the claimant, will be questioned first by the Minister’s counsel, then by the Division and then by the claimant’s counsel.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Order of questioning — Minister’s intervention not on exclusion issue
Subsection.Text: In a hearing of a claim for refugee protection, if the Minister is a party but has not intervened on an issue of exclusion under subrule 29(3), any witness, including the claimant, will be questioned first by the Division, then by the Minister’s counsel and then by the claimant’s counsel.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Order of questioning — application to vacate or cease refugee protection
Subsection.Text: In a hearing into an application to vacate or to cease refugee protection, any witness, including the protected person, is to be questioned first by the Minister’s counsel, then by the Division and then by the protected person’s counsel.
The Division must not vary the order of questioning unless there are exceptional circumstances, including that the variation is required to accommodate a vulnerable person.
The Division may limit the questioning of witnesses, including a claimant or a protected person, taking into account the nature and complexity of the issues and the relevance of the questions.
Representations must be made orally at the end of a hearing unless the Division orders otherwise.
A Division member must render an oral decision and reasons for the decision at the hearing unless it is not practicable to do so.

Heading.TitleText: Documents Establishing Identity and Other Elements of the Claim

Section.Text: The claimant must provide acceptable documents establishing their identity and other elements of the claim. A claimant who does not provide acceptable documents must explain why they did not provide the documents and what steps they took to obtain them.

Heading.TitleText: Application to Vacate or to Cease Refugee Protection

Section.Text: If an application to vacate or to cease refugee protection is made, the protected person must without delay notify the Division and the Minister in writing of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any change in their contact information; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: their counsel’s contact information and any limitations on the counsel’s retainer, if represented by counsel, and any changes to that information.

Section.MarginalNote: Declaration — counsel not representing or advising for consideration
Section.Text: If a protected person retains counsel who is not a person referred to in any of paragraphs 91(2)(a) to (c) of the Act, both the protected person and their counsel must without delay provide the information and declarations set out in Schedule 3 to the Division in writing.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subrule (2), as soon as counsel for a claimant or protected person agrees to a date for a proceeding, or as soon as a person becomes counsel after a date for a proceeding has been fixed, the counsel becomes counsel of record for the claimant or protected person.

If a claimant or protected person has notified the Division of a limitation on their counsel’s retainer, counsel is counsel of record only to the extent of the services to be provided within the limited retainer. Counsel ceases to be counsel of record as soon as those services are completed.

Section.MarginalNote: Request to be removed as counsel of record

Subsection.Text: To be removed as counsel of record, counsel for a claimant or protected person must first provide to the person represented and to the Minister, if the Minister is a party, a copy of a written request to be removed and then provide the written request to the Division, no later than three working days before the date fixed for the next proceeding.

If it is not possible for counsel to make the request in accordance with subrule (1), counsel must appear on the date fixed for the proceeding and make the request to be removed orally before the time fixed for the proceeding.
Counsel remains counsel of record unless the request to be removed is granted.

To remove counsel as counsel of record, a claimant or protected person must first provide to counsel and to the Minister, if the Minister is a party, a copy of a written notice that counsel is no longer counsel for the claimant or protected person, as the case may be, and then provide the written notice to the Division.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Ceasing to be counsel of record
Subsection.Text: Counsel ceases to be counsel of record as soon as the Division receives the notice.

Section.MarginalNote: Choice of language — claim for refugee protection

Subsection.Text: A claimant must choose English or French as the language of the proceedings at the time of the referral of their claim for refugee protection to the Division.

A claimant may change the language of the proceedings that they chose under subrule (1) by notifying the Division and the Minister in writing. The notice must be received by the Division and the Minister no later than 10 days before the date fixed for the next proceeding.

Section.MarginalNote: Choice of language — application to vacate or cease refugee protection

Subsection.Text: The language that is chosen under rule 17 is to be the language of the proceedings in any application made by the Minister to vacate or to cease refugee protection with respect to that claim.

A protected person may change the language of the proceedings by notifying the Division and the Minister in writing. The notice must be received by the Division and the Minister no later than 10 days before the date fixed for the next proceeding.

If a claimant needs an interpreter for the proceedings, the claimant must notify an officer at the time of the referral of the claim to the Division and specify the language and dialect, if any, to be interpreted.

A claimant may change the language and dialect, if any, that they specified under subrule (1), or if they had not indicated that an interpreter was needed, they may indicate that they need an interpreter, by notifying the Division in writing and indicating the language and dialect, if any, to be interpreted. The notice must be received by the Division no later than 10 days before the date fixed for the next proceeding.

If a protected person needs an interpreter for the proceedings, the protected person must notify the Division in writing and specify the language and dialect, if any, to be interpreted. The notice must be received by the Division no later than 10 days before the date fixed for the next proceeding.

If any party’s witness needs an interpreter for the proceedings, the party must notify the Division in writing and specify the language and dialect, if any, to be interpreted. The notice must be received by the Division no later than 10 days before the date fixed for the next proceeding.
The interpreter must take an oath or make a solemn affirmation to interpret accurately.

Section.MarginalNote: Duty of counsel or officer to notify

Subsection.Text: If counsel for a party or if an officer believes that the Division should designate a representative for the claimant or protected person because the claimant or protected person is under 18 years of age or is unable to appreciate the nature of the proceedings, counsel or the officer must without delay notify the Division in writing.

Subrule (1) does not apply in the case of a claimant under 18 years of age whose claim is joined with the claim of their parent or legal guardian if the parent or legal guardian is 18 years of age or older.
The notice must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether counsel or the officer is aware of a person in Canada who meets the requirements to be designated as a representative and, if so, the person’s contact information;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of any available supporting documents; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons why counsel or the officer believes that a representative should be designated.

Subsection.Text: To be designated as a representative, a person must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be 18 years of age or older;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: understand the nature of the proceedings;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be willing and able to act in the best interests of the claimant or protected person; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: not have interests that conflict with those of the claimant or protected person.

Subsection.Text: When determining whether a claimant or protected person is unable to appreciate the nature of the proceedings, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether the person can understand the reason for the proceeding and can instruct counsel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s statements and behaviour at the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: expert evidence, if any, on the person’s intellectual or physical faculties, age or mental condition; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: whether the person has had a representative designated for a proceeding in another division of the Board.

Subsection.Text: The designation of a representative for a person who is under 18 years of age or who is unable to appreciate the nature of the proceedings applies to all subsequent proceedings in the Division with respect to that person unless the Division orders otherwise.

Subsection.MarginalNote: End of designation — person reaches 18 years of age
Subsection.Text: The designation of a representative for a person who is under 18 years of age ends when the person reaches 18 years of age unless that representative has also been designated because the person is unable to appreciate the nature of the proceedings.
The Division may terminate a designation if the Division is of the opinion that the representative is no longer required or suitable and may designate a new representative if required.
Before designating a person as a representative, the Division must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: assess the person’s ability to fulfil the responsibilities of a designated representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the person has been informed of the responsibilities of a designated representative.

Subsection.Text: The responsibilities of a designated representative include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: deciding whether to retain counsel and, if counsel is retained, instructing counsel or assisting the represented person in instructing counsel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: making decisions regarding the claim or application or assisting the represented person in making those decisions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: informing the represented person about the various stages and procedures in the processing of their case;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: assisting in gathering evidence to support the represented person’s case and in providing evidence and, if necessary, being a witness at the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: protecting the interests of the represented person and putting forward the best possible case to the Division;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: informing and consulting the represented person to the extent possible when making decisions about the case; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: filing and perfecting an appeal to the Refugee Appeal Division, if required.

Section.MarginalNote: Disclosure of information from another claim

Subsection.Text: Subject to subrule (5), the Division may disclose to a claimant personal and other information that it wants to use from any other claim if the claims involve similar questions of fact or if the information is otherwise relevant to the determination of their claim.
If the personal or other information of another claimant has not been made public, the Division must make reasonable efforts to notify the other claimant in writing that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it intends to disclose the information to a claimant; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the other claimant may object to that disclosure.

Subsection.Text: In order to decide whether to object to the disclosure, the other claimant may make a written request to the Division for personal and other information relating to the claimant. Subject to subrule (5), the Division may disclose only information that is necessary to permit the other claimant to make an informed decision.
If the personal or other information of the claimant has not been made public, the Division must make reasonable efforts to notify the claimant in writing that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it intends to disclose the information to the other claimant; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant may object to that disclosure.

Subsection.Text: The Division must not disclose personal or other information unless it is satisfied that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: there is not a serious possibility that disclosing the information will endanger the life, liberty or security of any person; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: disclosing the information is not likely to cause an injustice.

Subsection.Text: Personal or other information from a joined claim is not subject to this rule. If claims were once joined but were later separated, only personal or other information that was provided before the separation is not subject to this rule.

Section.Text: Before using any information or opinion that is within its specialized knowledge, the Division must notify the claimant or protected person and, if the Minister is present at the hearing, the Minister, and give them an opportunity to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: make representations on the reliability and use of the information or opinion; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide evidence in support of their representations.

Heading.TitleText: Allowing a Claim Without a Hearing

Section.Text: For the purpose of paragraph 170(f) of the Act, the period during which the Minister must notify the Division of the Minister’s intention to intervene is no later than 10 days after the day on which the Minister receives the Basis of Claim Form.

Subsection.Text: The Division may require the parties to participate at a conference to fix a date for a proceeding or to discuss issues, relevant facts and any other matter to make the proceedings fairer and more efficient.
The Division may require the parties to give any information or provide any document, at or before the conference.
The Division must make a written record of any decisions and agreements made at the conference.
The Division must notify the claimant or protected person and the Minister in writing of the date, time and location of the proceeding.
In the case of a hearing on a refugee claim, the notice may be provided by an officer under paragraph 3(4)(a).

The date fixed for a hearing of a claim or an application to vacate or to cease refugee protection must not be earlier than 20 days after the day on which the parties receive the notice referred to in subrule (1) or (2) unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the hearing has been adjourned or postponed from an earlier date; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the parties consent to an earlier date.

Heading.TitleText: Exclusion, Integrity Issues, Inadmissibility and Ineligibility

Section.MarginalNote: Notice to Minister of possible exclusion before hearing

Subsection.Text: If the Division believes, before a hearing begins, that there is a possibility that section E or F of Article 1 of the Refugee Convention applies to the claim, the Division must without delay notify the Minister in writing and provide any relevant information to the Minister.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Notice to Minister of possible exclusion during hearing
Subsection.Text: If the Division believes, after a hearing begins, that there is a possibility that section E or F of Article 1 of the Refugee Convention applies to the claim and the Division is of the opinion that the Minister’s participation may help in the full and proper hearing of the claim, the Division must adjourn the hearing and without delay notify the Minister in writing and provide any relevant information to the Minister.
The Division must provide to the claimant a copy of any notice or information that the Division provides to the Minister.
The Division must fix a date for the resumption of the hearing that is as soon as practicable,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the Minister responds to the notice referred to in subrule (2), after receipt of the response from the Minister; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the Minister does not respond to that notice, no earlier than 14 days after receipt of the notice by the Minister.

Section.MarginalNote: Notice to Minister of possible integrity issues before hearing

Subsection.Text: If the Division believes, before a hearing begins, that there is a possibility that issues relating to the integrity of the Canadian refugee protection system may arise from the claim and the Division is of the opinion that the Minister’s participation may help in the full and proper hearing of the claim, the Division must without delay notify the Minister in writing and provide any relevant information to the Minister.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Notice to Minister of possible integrity issues during hearing
Subsection.Text: If the Division believes, after a hearing begins, that there is a possibility that issues relating to the integrity of the Canadian refugee protection system may arise from the claim and the Division is of the opinion that the Minister’s participation may help in the full and proper hearing of the claim, the Division must adjourn the hearing and without delay notify the Minister in writing and provide any relevant information to the Minister.
For the purpose of this rule, claims in which the possibility that issues relating to the integrity of the Canadian refugee protection system may arise include those in which there is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: information that the claim may have been made under a false identity in whole or in part;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a substantial change to the basis of the claim from that indicated in the Basis of Claim Form first provided to the Division;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: information that, in support of the claim, the claimant submitted documents that may be fraudulent; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: other information that the claimant may be directly or indirectly misrepresenting or withholding material facts relating to a relevant matter.

Subsection.Text: The Division must provide to the claimant a copy of any notice or information that the Division provides to the Minister.
The Division must fix a date for the resumption of the hearing that is as soon as practicable,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the Minister responds to the notice referred to in subrule (2), after receipt of the response from the Minister; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the Minister does not respond to that notice, no earlier than 14 days after receipt of the notice by the Minister.

Section.MarginalNote: Notice of possible inadmissibility or ineligibility

Subsection.Text: The Division must without delay notify the Minister in writing and provide the Minister with any relevant information if the Division believes that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a claimant may be inadmissible on grounds of security, violating human or international rights, serious criminality or organized criminality;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: there is an outstanding charge against the claimant for an offence under an Act of Parliament that is punishable by a maximum term of imprisonment of at least 10 years; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant’s claim may be ineligible to be referred under section 101 or paragraph 104(1)(c) or (d) of the Act.

Subsection.Text: The Division must provide to the claimant a copy of any notice or information that the Division provides to the Minister.

If, within 20 days after receipt of the notice referred to in subrule (1), the Minister does not notify the Division that the proceedings are suspended under paragraph 103(1)(a) or (b) of the Act or that the pending proceedings respecting the claim are terminated under section 104 of the Act, the Division may continue with the proceedings.
To intervene in a claim, the Minister must provide

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to the claimant, a copy of a notice of the Minister’s intention to intervene; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to the Division, the original of the notice, together with a written statement indicating how and when a copy was provided to the claimant.

Subsection.Text: In the notice, the Minister must state

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the purpose for which the Minister will intervene;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether the Minister will intervene in writing only, in person, or both; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister’s counsel’s contact information.

Subsection.Text: If the Minister believes that section E or F of Article 1 of the Refugee Convention may apply to the claim, the Minister must also state in the notice the facts and law on which the Minister relies.
Documents provided under this rule must be received by their recipients no later than 10 days before the date fixed for a hearing.

Heading.TitleText: Claimant or Protected Person in Custody

Section.Text: The Division may order a person who holds a claimant or protected person in custody to bring the claimant or protected person to a proceeding at a location specified by the Division.

Subsection.Text: A document prepared for use by a party in a proceeding must be typewritten, in a type not smaller than 12 point, on one or both sides of 216 mm by 279 mm (8 ½ inches x 11 inches) paper.
Any photocopy provided by a party must be a clear copy of the document photocopied and be on one or both sides of 216 mm by 279 mm (8 ½ inches x 11 inches) paper.
If more than one document is provided, the party must provide a list identifying each of the documents.
A party must consecutively number each page of all the documents provided as if they were one document.

Section.MarginalNote: Language of documents — claimant or protected person

Subsection.Text: All documents used by a claimant or protected person in a proceeding must be in English or French or, if in another language, be provided together with an English or French translation and a declaration signed by the translator.

All documents used by the Minister in a proceeding must be in the language of the proceeding or be provided together with a translation in the language of the proceeding and a declaration signed by the translator.
A translator’s declaration must include translator’s name, the language and dialect, if any, translated and a statement that the translation is accurate.
Subject to subrule (2), if the Division wants to use a document in a hearing, the Division must provide a copy of the document to each party.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Disclosure of country documentation by Division
Subsection.Text: The Division may disclose country documentation by providing to the parties a list of those documents or providing information as to where a list of those documents can be found on the Board’s website.
If a party wants to use a document in a hearing, the party must provide a copy of the document to the other party, if any, and to the Division.
The copy of the document provided to the Division must be accompanied by a written statement indicating how and when a copy of that document was provided to the other party, if any.
Documents provided under this rule must be received by their recipients no later than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 10 days before the date fixed for the hearing; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: five days before the date fixed for the hearing if the document is provided to respond to another document provided by a party or the Division.

Section.Text: Each document provided by a party for use at a proceeding must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be relevant to the particular proceeding; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: not duplicate other documents provided by a party or by the Division.

Section.Text: A party who does not provide a document in accordance with rule 34 must not use the document at the hearing unless allowed to do so by the Division. In deciding whether to allow its use, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the document’s relevance and probative value;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any new evidence the document brings to the hearing; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether the party, with reasonable effort, could have provided the document as required by rule 34.

Section.Text: Rules 38 to 41 apply to any document, including a notice or request in writing.

Subsection.Text: A document to be provided to the Division must be provided to the registry office specified by the Division.
A document to be provided to the Minister must be provided to the Minister’s counsel.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Providing documents to person other than Minister
Subsection.Text: A document to be provided to a person other than the Minister must be provided to the person’s counsel if the person has counsel of record. If the person does not have counsel of record, the document must be provided to the person.

Section.Text: Unless these Rules provide otherwise, a document may be provided in any of the following ways:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by hand;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by regular mail or registered mail;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: by courier;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: by fax if the recipient has a fax number and the document is no more than 20 pages long, unless the recipient consents to receiving more than 20 pages; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: by email or other electronic means if the Division allows.

Section.MarginalNote: Application if unable to provide document

Subsection.Text: If a party is unable to provide a document in a way required by rule 39, the party may make an application to the Division to be allowed to provide the document in another way or to be excused from providing the document.
The application must be made in accordance with rule 50.
The Division must not allow the application unless the party has made reasonable efforts to provide the document to the person to whom the document must be provided.
A document provided to the Division is considered to be received by the Division on the day on which the document is date-stamped by the Division.

Subsection.MarginalNote: When document received by recipient other than Division
Subsection.Text: A document provided by regular mail other than to the Division is considered to be received seven days after the day on which it was mailed. If the seventh day is not a working day, the document is considered to be received on the next working day.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Extension of time limit — next working day
Subsection.Text: When the time limit for providing a document ends on a day that is not a working day, the time limit is extended to the next working day.
A party who has provided a copy of a document to the Division must provide the original document to the Division

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: without delay, on the written request of the Division; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the Division does not make a request, no later than at the beginning of the proceeding at which the document will be used.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Documents referred to in paragraph 3(5)(e) or (g)
Subsection.Text: On the written request of the Division, the Minister must without delay provide to the Division the original of any document referred to in paragraph 3(5)(e) or (g) that is in the possession of an officer.
A party who wants to provide a document as evidence after a hearing but before a decision takes effect must make an application to the Division.
The party must attach a copy of the document to the application that must be made in accordance with rule 50, but the party is not required to give evidence in an affidavit or statutory declaration.
In deciding the application, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the document’s relevance and probative value;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any new evidence the document brings to the proceedings; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether the party, with reasonable effort, could have provided the document as required by rule 34.

Subsection.Text: If a party wants to call a witness, the party must provide the following witness information in writing to the other party, if any, and to the Division:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the witness’s contact information;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a brief statement of the purpose and substance of the witness’s testimony or, in the case of an expert witness, the expert witness’s brief signed summary of the testimony to be given;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the time needed for the witness’s testimony;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the party’s relationship to the witness;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an expert witness, a description of the expert witness’s qualifications; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: whether the party wants the witness to testify by means of live telecommunication.

Subsection.Text: The witness information provided to the Division must be accompanied by a written statement indicating how and when it was provided to the other party, if any.
Documents provided under this rule must be received by their recipients no later than 10 days before the date fixed for the hearing.
If a party does not provide the witness information, the witness must not testify at the hearing unless the Division allows them to testify.
In deciding whether to allow a witness to testify, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the relevance and probative value of the proposed testimony; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reason why the witness information was not provided.

Subsection.Text: A party who wants the Division to order a person to testify at a hearing must make a request to the Division for a summons, either orally at a proceeding or in writing.
In deciding whether to issue a summons, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the necessity of the testimony to a full and proper hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s ability to give that testimony; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether the person has agreed to be summoned as a witness.

Subsection.Text: If a party wants to use a summons, the party must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide the summons to the person by hand;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide a copy of the summons to the Division, together with a written statement indicating the name of the person who provided the summons and the date, time and place that it was provided by hand; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: pay or offer to pay the person the applicable witness fees and travel expenses set out in Tariff A of the Federal Courts Rules.

Subsection.Text: If a person who is summoned to appear as a witness wants the summons cancelled, the person must make an application in writing to the Division.
The person must make the application in accordance with rule 50, but is not required to give evidence in an affidavit or statutory declaration.

If a person does not obey a summons to appear as a witness, the party who requested the summons may make a request to the Division orally at the hearing, or in writing, to issue a warrant for the person’s arrest.
A party who makes a written request for a warrant must provide supporting evidence by affidavit or statutory declaration.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Requirements for issue of arrest warrant
Subsection.Text: The Division must not issue a warrant unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person was provided the summons by hand or the person is avoiding being provided the summons;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person was paid or offered the applicable witness fees and travel expenses set out in Tariff A of the Federal Courts Rules;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person did not appear at the hearing as required by the summons; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s testimony is still needed for a full and proper hearing.

Subsection.Text: A warrant issued by the Division for the arrest of a person must include directions concerning detention or release.

Section.Text: If the Division excludes a witness from a hearing room, no person may communicate to the witness any evidence given while the witness was excluded unless allowed to do so by the Division or until the witness has finished testifying.
Unless these Rules provide otherwise,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a party who wants the Division to make a decision on any matter in a proceeding, including the procedure to be followed, must make an application to the Division in accordance with rule 50;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a party who wants to respond to the application must respond in accordance with rule 51; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a party who wants to reply to a response must reply in accordance with rule 52.

Subsection.Text: Unless these Rules provide otherwise, an application must be made in writing, without delay, and must be received by the Division no later than 10 days before the date fixed for the next proceeding.
The Division must not allow a party to make an application orally at a proceeding unless the party, with reasonable effort, could not have made a written application before the proceeding.
Unless these Rules provide otherwise, in a written application, the party must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: state the decision the party wants the Division to make;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: give reasons why the Division should make that decision; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if there is another party and the views of that party are known, state whether the other party agrees to the application.

Subsection.Text: Unless these Rules provide otherwise, any evidence that the party wants the Division to consider with a written application must be given in an affidavit or statutory declaration that accompanies the application.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Providing application to other party and Division
Subsection.Text: A party who makes a written application must provide

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to the other party, if any, a copy of the application and a copy of any affidavit or statutory declaration; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to the Division, the original application and the original of any affidavit or statutory declaration, together with a written statement indicating how and when the party provided a copy to the other party, if any.

Heading.TitleText: How to Respond to a Written Application

Subsection.Text: A response to a written application must be in writing and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: state the decision the party wants the Division to make; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: give reasons why the Division should make that decision.

Subsection.Text: Any evidence that the party wants the Division to consider with the written response must be given in an affidavit or statutory declaration that accompanies the response. Unless the Division requires it, an affidavit or statutory declaration is not required if the party who made the application was not required to give evidence in an affidavit or statutory declaration, together with the application.
A party who responds to a written application must provide

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to the other party, a copy of the response and a copy of any affidavit or statutory declaration; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to the Division, the original response and the original of any affidavit or statutory declaration, together with a written statement indicating how and when the party provided a copy to the other party.

Subsection.Text: Documents provided under subrule (3) must be received by their recipients no later than five days after the date on which the party receives the copy of the application.

Heading.TitleText: How to Reply to a Written Response

Subsection.Text: A reply to a written response must be in writing.

Any evidence that the party wants the Division to consider with the written reply must be given in an affidavit or statutory declaration that accompanies the reply. Unless the Division requires it, an affidavit or statutory declaration is not required if the party was not required to give evidence in an affidavit or statutory declaration, together with the application.
A party who replies to a written response must provide

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to the other party, a copy of the reply and a copy of any affidavit or statutory declaration; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to the Division, the original reply and the original of any affidavit or statutory declaration, together with a written statement indicating how and when the party provided a copy to the other party.

Subsection.Text: Documents provided under subrule (3) must be received by their recipients no later than three days after the date on which the party receives the copy of the response.

Heading.TitleText: Changing the Location of a Proceeding

Subsection.Text: A party may make an application to the Division to change the location of a proceeding.
The party must make the application in accordance with rule 50, but is not required to give evidence in an affidavit or statutory declaration.
Documents provided under this rule must be received by their recipients no later than 20 days before the date fixed for the proceeding.
In deciding the application, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether the party is residing in the location where the party wants the proceeding to be held;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether a change of location would allow the proceeding to be full and proper;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether a change of location would likely delay the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: how a change of location would affect the Division’s operation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: how a change of location would affect the parties;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: whether a change of location is necessary to accommodate a vulnerable person; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: whether a hearing may be conducted by a means of live telecommunication with the claimant or protected person.

Subsection.Text: Unless a party receives a decision from the Division allowing the application, the party must appear for the proceeding at the location fixed and be ready to start or continue the proceeding.

Heading.TitleText: Changing the Date or Time of a Proceeding

Subsection.Text: Subject to subrule (5), an application to change the date or time of a proceeding must be made in accordance with rule 50, but the party is not required to give evidence in an affidavit or statutory declaration.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Time limit and content of application
Subsection.Text: The application must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be made without delay;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be received by the Division no later than three working days before the date fixed for the proceeding, unless the application is made for medical reasons or other emergencies; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: include at least three dates and times, which are no later than 10 working days after the date originally fixed for the proceeding, on which the party is available to start or continue the proceeding.

Subsection.Text: If it is not possible for the party to make the application in accordance with paragraph (2)(b), the party must appear on the date fixed for the proceeding and make the application orally before the time fixed for the proceeding.
Subject to subrule (5), the Division must not allow the application unless there are exceptional circumstances, such as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the change is required to accommodate a vulnerable person; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an emergency or other development outside the party’s control and the party has acted diligently.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Counsel retained or availability of counsel provided after hearing date fixed
Subsection.Text: If, at the time the officer fixed the hearing date under subrule 3(1), a claimant did not have counsel or was unable to provide the dates when their counsel would be available to attend a hearing, the claimant may make an application to change the date or time of the hearing. Subject to operational limitations, the Division must allow the application if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant retains counsel no later than five working days after the day on which the hearing date was fixed by the officer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the counsel retained is not available on the date fixed for the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the application is made in writing;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the application is made without delay and no later than five working days after the day on which the hearing date was fixed by the officer; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant provides at least three dates and times when counsel is available, which are within the time limits set out in the Regulations for the hearing of the claim.

Subsection.Text: If a claimant or protected person makes the application for medical reasons, other than those related to their counsel, they must provide, together with the application, a legible, recently dated medical certificate signed by a qualified medical practitioner whose name and address are printed or stamped on the certificate. A claimant or protected person who has provided a copy of the certificate to the Division must provide the original document to the Division without delay.
The medical certificate must set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the particulars of the medical condition, without specifying the diagnosis, that prevent the claimant or protected person from participating in the proceeding on the date fixed for the proceeding; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the claimant or protected person is expected to be able to participate in the proceeding.

Subsection.Text: If a claimant or protected person fails to provide a medical certificate in accordance with subrules (6) and (7), they must include in their application

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: particulars of any efforts they made to obtain the required medical certificate, supported by corroborating evidence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: particulars of the medical reasons for the application, supported by corroborating evidence; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an explanation of how the medical condition prevents them from participating in the proceeding on the date fixed for the proceeding.

Subsection.Text: If the party made a previous application that was denied, the Division must consider the reasons for the denial and must not allow the subsequent application unless there are exceptional circumstances supported by new evidence.
Unless a party receives a decision from the Division allowing the application, the party must appear for the proceeding at the date and time fixed and be ready to start or continue the proceeding.

If an application for a change to the date or time of a proceeding is allowed, the new date fixed by the Division must be no later than 10 working days after the date originally fixed for the proceeding or as soon as possible after that date.

Heading.TitleText: Joining or Separating Claims or Applications

Subsection.Text: The Division must join the claim of a claimant to a claim made by the claimant’s spouse or common-law partner, child, parent, legal guardian, brother, sister, grandchild or grandparent, unless it is not practicable to do so.
Applications to vacate or to cease refugee protection are joined if the claims of the protected persons were joined.
A party may make an application to the Division to join claims or applications to vacate or to cease refugee protection.
A party may make an application to the Division to separate claims or applications to vacate or to cease refugee protection that are joined.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Form of application and providing application
Subsection.Text: A party who makes an application to join or separate claims or applications to vacate or to cease refugee protection must do so in accordance with rule 50, but the party is not required to give evidence in an affidavit or statutory declaration. The party must also

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide a copy of the application to any person who will be affected by the Division’s decision on the application; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide to the Division a written statement indicating how and when the copy of the application was provided to any affected person, together with proof that the party provided the copy to that person.

Subsection.Text: Documents provided under this rule must be received by their recipients no later than 20 days before the date fixed for the hearing.
In deciding the application to join or separate, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including whether

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the claims or applications to vacate or to cease refugee protection involve similar questions of fact or law;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: allowing the application to join or separate would promote the efficient administration of the Division’s work; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: allowing the application to join or separate would likely cause an injustice.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of this rule, the Minister is considered to be a party whether or not the Minister takes part in the proceedings.
A person who makes an application to the Division to have a proceeding conducted in public must do so in writing and in accordance with this rule rather than rule 50.
The Division must not allow a person to make an application orally at a proceeding unless the person, with reasonable effort, could not have made a written application before the proceeding.
In the application, the person must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: state the decision they want the Division to make;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: give reasons why the Division should make that decision;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: state whether they want the Division to consider the application in public or in the absence of the public;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: give reasons why the Division should consider the application in public or in the absence of the public;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if they want the Division to hear the application orally, give reasons why the Division should do so; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: include any evidence that they want the Division to consider in deciding the application.

Subsection.Text: The person must provide the original application together with two copies to the Division. The Division must provide a copy of the application to the parties.
A party may respond to a written application. The response must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: state the decision they want the Division to make;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: give reasons why the Division should make that decision;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: state whether they want the Division to consider the application in public or in the absence of the public;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: give reasons why the Division should consider the application in public or in the absence of the public;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if they want the Division to hear the application orally, give reasons why the Division should do so; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: include any evidence that they want the Division to consider in deciding the application.

Subsection.Text: The party must provide a copy of the response to the other party and provide the original response and a copy to the Division, together with a written statement indicating how and when the party provided the copy to the other party.
The Division must provide to the applicant either a copy of the response or a summary of the response referred to in paragraph (12)(a).
An applicant or a party may reply in writing to a written response or a summary of a response.

An applicant or a party who replies to a written response or a summary of a response must provide the original reply and two copies to the Division. The Division must provide a copy of the reply to the parties.
An application made under this rule must be received by the Division without delay. The Division must specify the time limit within which a response or reply, if any, is to be provided.
The Division may take any measures it considers necessary to ensure the confidentiality of the proceeding in respect of the application, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: providing a summary of the response to the applicant instead of a copy; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the Division holds a hearing in respect of the application,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: excluding the applicant or the applicant and their counsel from the hearing while the party responding to the application provides evidence and makes representations, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: allowing the presence of the applicant’s counsel at the hearing while the party responding to the application provides evidence and makes representations, upon receipt of a written undertaking by counsel not to disclose any evidence or information adduced until a decision is made to hold the hearing in public.

Subsection.Text: If the Division provides a summary of the response under paragraph (12)(a), or excludes the applicant and their counsel from a hearing in respect of the application under subparagraph (12)(b)(i), the Division must provide a summary of the representations and evidence, if any, that is sufficient to enable the applicant to reply, while ensuring the confidentiality of the proceeding having regard to the factors set out in paragraph 166(b) of the Act.
The Division must notify the applicant and the parties of its decision on the application and provide reasons for the decision.

An application under rule 57 is not necessary if an observer is a member of the staff of the Board or a representative or agent of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees or if the claimant or protected person consents to or requests the presence of an observer other than a representative of the press or other media of communication at the proceeding.
The Division must allow the attendance of an observer unless, in the opinion of the Division, the observer’s attendance is likely to impede the proceeding.
The Division may take any measures that it considers necessary to ensure the confidentiality of the proceeding despite the presence of an observer.

For the purpose of subsection 168(2) of the Act, withdrawal of a claim or of an application to vacate or to cease refugee protection is an abuse of process if withdrawal would likely have a negative effect on the Division’s integrity. If no substantive evidence has been accepted in the hearing, withdrawal is not an abuse of process.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Withdrawal if no substantive evidence accepted
Subsection.Text: If no substantive evidence has been accepted in the hearing, a party may withdraw the party’s claim or the application to vacate or to cease refugee protection by notifying the Division orally at a proceeding or in writing.

If substantive evidence has been accepted in the hearing, a party who wants to withdraw the party’s claim or the application to vacate or to cease refugee protection must make an application to the Division in accordance with rule 50.

Heading.TitleText: Reinstating a Withdrawn Claim or Application

Subsection.Text: A person may make an application to the Division to reinstate a claim that was made by the person and was withdrawn.

The person must make the application in accordance with rule 50, include in the application their contact information and, if represented by counsel, their counsel’s contact information and any limitations on counsel’s retainer, and provide a copy of the application to the Minister.

The Division must not allow the application unless it is established that there was a failure to observe a principle of natural justice or it is otherwise in the interests of justice to allow the application.
In deciding the application, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including whether the application was made in a timely manner and the justification for any delay.

If the person made a previous application to reinstate that was denied, the Division must consider the reasons for the denial and must not allow the subsequent application unless there are exceptional circumstances supported by new evidence.

Section.MarginalNote: Application to reinstate withdrawn application to vacate or to cease refugee protection

Subsection.Text: The Minister may make an application to the Division to reinstate an application to vacate or to cease refugee protection that was withdrawn.
The Minister must make the application in accordance with rule 50.

The Division must not allow the application unless it is established that there was a failure to observe a principle of natural justice or it is otherwise in the interests of justice to allow the application.
In deciding the application, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including whether the application was made in a timely manner and the justification for any delay.

If the Minister made a previous application to reinstate that was denied, the Division must consider the reasons for the denial and must not allow the subsequent application unless there are exceptional circumstances supported by new evidence.

At any time before the Refugee Appeal Division or the Federal Court has made a final determination in respect of a claim for refugee protection that has been decided or declared abandoned, the claimant or the Minister may make an application to the Division to reopen the claim.
The application must be made in accordance with rule 50 and, for the purpose of paragraph 50(5)(a), the Minister is considered to be a party whether or not the Minister took part in the proceedings.

If a claimant makes the application, they must include in the application their contact information and, if represented by counsel, their counsel’s contact information and any limitations on counsel’s retainer.
If it is alleged in the application that the claimant’s counsel in the proceedings that are the subject of the application provided inadequate representation,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant must first provide a copy of the application to the counsel and then provide the original application to the Division, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the application provided to the Division must be accompanied by a written statement indicating how and when the copy of the application was provided to the counsel.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Copy of notice of appeal or pending application
Subsection.Text: The application must be accompanied by a copy of any notice of pending appeal or any pending application for leave to apply for judicial review or any pending application for judicial review.
The Division must not allow the application unless it is established that there was a failure to observe a principle of natural justice.
In deciding the application, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether the application was made in a timely manner and the justification for any delay; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons why

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a party who had the right of appeal to the Refugee Appeal Division did not appeal, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a party did not make an application for leave to apply for judicial review or an application for judicial review.

Subsection.Text: If the party made a previous application to reopen that was denied, the Division must consider the reasons for the denial and must not allow the subsequent application unless there are exceptional circumstances supported by new evidence.

If there is a pending appeal to the Refugee Appeal Division or a pending application for leave to apply for judicial review or a pending application for judicial review on the same or similar grounds, the Division must, as soon as is practicable, allow the application to reopen if it is necessary for the timely and efficient processing of a claim, or dismiss the application.

Section.MarginalNote: Application to reopen application to vacate or to cease refugee protection

Subsection.Text: At any time before the Federal Court has made a final determination in respect of an application to vacate or to cease refugee protection that has been decided or declared abandoned, the Minister or the protected person may make an application to the Division to reopen the application.
The application must be made in accordance with rule 50.

If a protected person makes the application, they must include in the application their contact information and, if represented by counsel, their counsel’s contact information and any limitations on counsel’s retainer, and they must provide a copy of the application to the Minister.
If it is alleged in the application that the protected person’s counsel in the proceedings that are the subject of the application to reopen provided inadequate representation,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the protected person must first provide a copy of the application to the counsel and then provide the original application to the Division, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the application provided to the Division must be accompanied by a written statement indicating how and when the copy of the application was provided to the counsel.

Subsection.Text: The application must be accompanied by a copy of any pending application for leave to apply for judicial review or any pending application for judicial review in respect of the application to vacate or to cease refugee protection.
The Division must not allow the application unless it is established that there was a failure to observe a principle of natural justice.
In deciding the application, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether the application was made in a timely manner and the justification for any delay; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if a party did not make an application for leave to apply for judicial review or an application for judicial review, the reasons why an application was not made.

Subsection.Text: If the party made a previous application to reopen that was denied, the Division must consider the reasons for the denial and must not allow the subsequent application unless there are exceptional circumstances supported by new evidence.

If there is a pending application for leave to apply for judicial review or a pending application for judicial review on the same or similar grounds, the Division must, as soon as is practicable, allow the application to reopen if it is necessary for the timely and efficient processing of a claim, or dismiss the application.

Heading.TitleText: Applications to Vacate or to Cease Refugee Protection

Subsection.Text: An application to vacate or to cease refugee protection made by the Minister must be in writing and made in accordance with this rule.
In the application, the Minister must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the contact information of the protected person and of their counsel, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the identification number given by the Department of Citizenship and Immigration to the protected person;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date and file number of any Division decision with respect to the protected person;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a person whose application for protection was allowed abroad, the person’s file number, a copy of the decision and the location of the office;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the decision that the Minister wants the Division to make; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons why the Division should make that decision.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Providing application to protected person and Division
Subsection.Text: The Minister must provide

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the application to the protected person; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the original of the application to the registry office that provided the notice of decision in the claim or to a registry office specified by the Division, together with a written statement indicating how and when a copy was provided to the protected person.

Subsection.Text: In determining whether a claim has been abandoned under subsection 168(1) of the Act, the Division must give the claimant an opportunity to explain why the claim should not be declared abandoned,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: immediately, if the claimant is present at the proceeding and the Division considers that it is fair to do so; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, by way of a special hearing.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Special hearing — Basis of Claim Form
Subsection.Text: The special hearing on the abandonment of the claim for the failure to provide a completed Basis of Claim Form in accordance with paragraph 7(5)(a) must be held no later than five working days after the day on which the completed Basis of Claim Form was due. At the special hearing, the claimant must provide their completed Basis of Claim Form, unless the form has already been provided to the Division.

The special hearing on the abandonment of the claim for the failure to appear for the hearing of the claim must be held no later than five working days after the day originally fixed for the hearing of the claim.

The Division must consider, in deciding if the claim should be declared abandoned, the explanation given by the claimant and any other relevant factors, including the fact that the claimant is ready to start or continue the proceedings.

If the claimant’s explanation includes medical reasons, other than those related to their counsel, they must provide, together with the explanation, the original of a legible, recently dated medical certificate signed by a qualified medical practitioner whose name and address are printed or stamped on the certificate.
The medical certificate must set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the particulars of the medical condition, without specifying the diagnosis, that prevented the claimant from providing the completed Basis of Claim Form on the due date, appearing for the hearing of the claim, or otherwise pursuing their claim, as the case may be; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the claimant is expected to be able to pursue their claim.

Subsection.Text: If a claimant fails to provide a medical certificate in accordance with subrules (5) and (6), the claimant must include in their explanation

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: particulars of any efforts they made to obtain the required medical certificate, supported by corroborating evidence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: particulars of the medical reasons included in the explanation, supported by corroborating evidence; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an explanation of how the medical condition prevented them from providing the completed Basis of Claim Form on the due date, appearing for the hearing of the claim or otherwise pursuing their claim, as the case may be.
